description: From Middle English cofre, coffre, from Old French cofre, coffre, from Latin cophinus (“basket”), from Ancient Greek κόφινος (kóphinos, “basket”). Doublet of coffin.

entries.meaning: A strong chest or box used for keeping money or valuables safe.
(architecture) An ornamental sunken panel in a ceiling or dome.
A supply or store of money, often belonging to an organization.
examples: He would discharge it without any great burden to the queen's coffers.

entries.meaning: A trench dug in the bottom of a dry moat, and extending across it, to enable the besieged to defend it with raking fire.

verbs.description: coffer (third-person singular simple present coffers, present participle coffering, simple past and past participle coffered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To put money or valuables in a coffer
(transitive) To decorate something, especially a ceiling, with coffers.
